Welcome to TRAC Documentation’s documentation!

Note

Global Project Note - TRAC Version 1.0

The TRAC project represents a significant stride in the specification and verification of coordinated multiparty distributed systems, specifically tailored to enhance the modeling and analysis of distributed protocols akin to blockchain smart contracts. By integrating the versatility of finite-state machines (FSMs) with advanced features like guards, assignments, and participant binders, TRAC sets a new benchmark for articulating complex coordination scenarios that involve a dynamic and potentially unbounded number of participants.

This initial version (1.0) of TRAC underscores our commitment to addressing the intricate challenges inherent in distributed system specifications. The introduction of a well-formedness criterion marks a pivotal step towards eliminating specifications that could lead to ambiguity or misinterpretation, thereby reinforcing the semantic integrity of the systems designed with TRAC.

However, as with any pioneering software tool in its nascent stage, TRAC version 1.0 is a work in progress. The current release lays the groundwork for sophisticated specification and verification capabilities but also highlights the path for future enhancements and optimizations. The project is currently in a phase where iterative improvements, feedback, and practical applications will be crucial in refining its functionality and broadening its applicability.

Users are advised to approach TRAC with an understanding of its developmental status. While the tool opens up new avenues for specifying and verifying distributed systems, particularly those modeled on smart contracts, it is essential to recognize that there may be limitations, undiscovered bugs, or unoptimized aspects at this stage. As such, users should exercise caution, especially when integrating TRAC into critical or production-grade projects.

We warmly invite the community to engage with TRAC—through testing, providing feedback, or contributing to its development. Your insights and experiences are invaluable as we endeavor to evolve TRAC into a more robust and versatile tool capable of meeting the diverse needs of distributed system developers and researchers.

As we continue to advance TRAC, we are excited about the possibilities it heralds for the future of distributed system specification and verification. We look forward to collaborating with the community to explore these possibilities and to collectively push the boundaries of what can be achieved in this dynamic field.
